sen.j: 社格（しゃかく）とは、神社の格式。
sen.e: Shakaku is a ranking system for Shinto shrines.
Shakaku is a ranking system for Shinto shrines.
Shakaku is a ranking system for Shinto shrines.

sen.j: 祭政一致に基づき、朝廷などにより定められる。
sen.e: It was established by the imperial court, as part of the unification of religion and government.
It was established by the Imperial Court based on the unity of religion and politics.
sen.cmt: the imperial court→the Imperial Court （辞書に大文字で表記あり） 原文に”基づき”とあるので、文の後半をbased on the unity of religion and politicsに修正。
sen.e: It was established by the Imperial Court based on the unity of religion and politics.

tit.cmt: 上古→最も古い時代とある。

sen.j: 天津社
天津神を祀る神社。
sen.e: A shrine venerating the god Amatsu-kami
sen.cmt: kamiはgodと同じ意味なので、重ならないように修正。

sen.j: 国津社
国津神を祀る神社。
sen.e: A shrine venerating the god Kunitsu-kami
sen.cmt: kamiはgodと同じ意味なので、重ならないように修正。

tit.e: The Ancient Times/Middle Ages Shakaku System
tit.cmt: 時代という内容を挿入。
tit.e: The Ancient Times/Middle Ages Shakaku System

sen.j: 延喜式による社格制度
sen.e: Shakaku System Based on the Engi-shiki
The Shakaku System Based on the Engi-shiki
The Shakaku System Based on the Engi-shiki

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳に記載されている神社を式内社（しきないしゃ）といい、延喜式の時代に明らかに存在していても延喜式神名帳に記載されていない神社を式外社（しきげしゃ）という。
sen.e: Shrines that were listed in the Engi-shiki Jimmyo-cho are called Shikinaisha; while those that clearly existed at the time but were not listed are called Shikigesha.
Shrines that were listed in the Engi-shiki Jimmyo-cho are called Shikinaisha; while those that clearly existed at the time but were not listed in it are called Shikigesha.
Shrines that were listed in the Engi-shiki Jimmyo-cho are called Shikinaisha; while those that clearly existed at the time but were not listed in it are called Shikigesha.

sen.j: 式内社は祈年祭奉幣を受けるべき神社であり、2861社が記載されている。
sen.e: The Shikinaisha are those shrines that received a Kinen-sai offering; there were 2,861 of them listed.
The Shikinaisha are those shrines were entitled to offerings at Kinen-sai; there were 2,861 of them listed.
sen.cmt: 原文に”受けるべき”とあるので修正。また奉幣は複数。
sen.e: The Shikinaisha are those shrines were entitled to offerings at Kinen-sai; there were 2,861 of them listed.

sen.j: これらは当時朝廷から重視された神社であることを示している。
sen.e: This signifies that the imperial court placed importance on these shrines at the time.
This signifies that the Imperial Court placed importance on these shrines at the time.
sen.cmt: the imperial court→the Imperial Court （辞書に大文字で表記あり）
sen.e: This signifies that the Imperial Court placed importance on these shrines at the time.

sen.j: 式内社には、古来より霊験が著しいとされる名神を祀る神社が全て含まれており、それらを名神大社（名神大）という。
sen.e: Those that enshrine Myojin gods, long thought to have a particularly strong presence, are all included in the Shikinaisha, and are called Myojin Taisha (Myojindai).
Those that enshrine Myojin (gods), long thought to have a remarkably miraculous efficacy, are all included in the Shikinaisha, and are called Myojin Taisha (Myojindai).
sen.cmt: Myojin gods→Myojin (gods) Myojinは、神の称号の一つ。神という意味が明神に含まれているので、重ならないように修正。 原文の”霊験が著しい”を修正。
sen.e: Those that enshrine Myojin (gods), long thought to have a remarkably miraculous efficacy, are all included in the Shikinaisha, and are calledMyojin Taisha Shrine (Myojidai).

sen.j: 官幣社は神祇官より奉幣を受ける神社で、国幣社は国司より奉幣を受ける神社である。
sen.e: Kanpeisha are the shrines that received an offering from the Jingikan; and Kokuheisha are those that received an offering from a Kokushi.
The Kanpeisha are the shrines that received offerings from the Jingikan (the Department of Divinities); and the Kokuheisha are those that received offerings from the Kokushi (local governors).
sen.cmt: theを2カ所補足。Kokushiの前のaをtheに修正。神祇官と国司の訳を補足。offering→offerings
sen.e: TheKanpei-sha Shrine are the shrines that received offerings from the Jingikan (the Department of Divinities); and the Kokuhei-sha Shrine are those that received offerings from the Kokushi (local governors).

sen.j: それぞれに大・小の格が定められている。
sen.e: Each has Major (dai) and Minor (sho) designations.
Each shrine was ranked by Major (dai) and Minor (sho).
sen.cmt: 原文に忠実になるように修正。
sen.e: Each shrine was ranked by Major (dai) and Minor (sho).

sen.j: 当初は全て神祇官から直接奉幣を受けていたが、遠国の神社についてはそこへ行くまでに時間がかかることから、国司が代理で行うようになり、官幣社・国幣社の別ができた。
sen.e: At first they all got offerings directly from the Jingikan; but because it took time to travel to shrines in distant districts, the Kokushi began to conduct offerings on his behalf, creating the distinction between Kanpeisha and Kokuheisha.

At first all shrines got offerings directly from the Jingikan; but because it took time to travel to shrines in distant districts, the Kokushi began to conduct offerings on behalf of the Jingikan, creating the distinction between Kanpeisha and Kokuheisha.
sen.cmt: they→all shrines on his behalf→on behalf of the Jingikan 何を指しているのかがわかるように修正。
sen.e: At first all shrines got offerings directly from the Jingikan; but because it took time to travel to shrines in distant districts, the Kokushi began to conduct offerings on behalf of the Jingikan, creating the distinction between Kanpeisha and Kokuheisha.

sen.j: ただし、遠国であっても重要な神社は官幣社となっていた。
sen.e: Actually, some important shrines were Kanpeisha, even if they were in far away districts.
However, some important shrines became Kanpeisha, even if they were in distant districts.
However, some important shrines became Kanpeisha, even if they were in distant districts.

sen.j: 社格の順は以下の通り。
sen.e: The order of Shakaku is as follows.
The order of Shakaku is as follows.
The order of Shakaku is as follows.

sen.j: 官幣大社
国幣大社
官幣小社
国幣小社
一宮
一宮は令制国で一番有力な神社。
sen.e: An Ichinomiya was the most powerful shrine in a district.
Ichinomiya was the most powerful shrine in the country of Ryo-sei (the political system based on the ritsuryo codes).
sen.cmt: An Ichinomiya→Ichinomiya 律令→the legal codes of the Nara and Heian periods 令制＝律令制→the political system based on the ritsuryo codes
sen.e: Ichinomiya was the most powerful shrine in the country of Ryo-sei (the political system based on the ritsuryo codes).

sen.j: 国司が任国に赴任したときに神拝といって任国内の神社を巡拝しなければならなかった。
sen.e: When a Kokushi began his appointment, he had to make a pilgrimage to the shrines in his district.
When a Kokushi began his appointment, he had to make a pilgrimage to the shrines(called Sinpai) in his district.
sen.cmt: 原文にある”神拝”を補足。
sen.e: When a Kokushi began his appointment, he had to make a pilgrimage to the shrines(called Sinpai) in his district.

sen.j: その中でもっとも有力な神社を一宮と呼ぶようになり、一番初めに参拝し、国によっては二宮、三宮も存在した。
sen.e: The most influential shrine in the district came to be called Ichinomiya, as it was the first that he would visit; some districts had a Ninomiya or Sannomiya.
The most influential shrine in the district came to be called Ichinomiya, as it was the first that he would visit; some districts had Ninomiya and also Sannomiya.
The most influential shrine in the district came to be called Ichinomiya, as it was the first that he would visit; some districts had Ninomiya and also Sannomiya.

sen.j: 明確な規定はなく神社の盛衰によるため時代によって異なる。
sen.e: As there are no clear criteria, it changed throughout history, according to the ups and downs of the shrines.
As there were no clear criteria, it changed throughout history, according to the ups and downs of the shrines.
As there were no clear criteria, it changed throughout history, according to the ups and downs of the shrines.

sen.j: 平安時代後期から、地方より始まり、やがて畿内でも定められた。
sen.e: It began in the provinces in the late Heian period, and eventually spread to the Kinai area.
It began in the provinces in the late Heian period, and was eventually established in the Kinai area too.
sen.cmt: 原文には、”定められた”とあるので修正。
sen.e: It began in the provinces in the late Heian period, and was eventually established in the Kinai area too.

sen.j: 惣社(総社)
国司の神拝の際、任国内の神社を巡拝してまわるには手間がかかるので、国府の近くに神社をまとめて合祀した。
sen.e: Because it took the Kokushi a long time to visit all of the shrines in the district, they would be bundled together near the seat of government.
Because it took the Kokushi a long time to visit all of the shrines in the district, they were enshrined together in the vicinity of provincial government offices.
Because it took the Kokushi a long time to visit all of the shrines in the district, they were enshrined together in the vicinity of provincial government offices.

sen.j: それが総社(惣社)である。
sen.cmt: 過去に名付けられたので修正。

sen.j: 国司奉幣社
国司奉幣社は各国の国内神名帳に記載のある神社。
sen.e: Kokushi Hoheisha are the shrines in each district that are listed in its Kokunai Jimmyo-cho.
The Kokushi Hoheisha are the shrines that are listed in Kokunai Jimmyo-cho of each district.
The Kokushi Hoheisha are the shrines that are listed in Kokunai Jimmyo-cho of each district.

sen.j: 国内神名帳は、国司が神拝する際に参拝する神社のリスト。
sen.e: A Kokunai Jimmyo-cho is a list of the shrines that the Kokushi visited when he made his pilgrimage.
Kokunai Jimmyo-cho is a list of the shrines that the Kokushi visited when he made his pilgrimage.
Kokunai Jimmyo-cho is a list of the shrines that the Kokushi visited when he made his pilgrimage.

sen.j: ただし、これは一部の国のものしか現存せず、現存しているものも多くが写本や抄本のため、正確な実体や総数などは分からない。
sen.e: Actually, these are only remaining from a few districts, and even most of those are copies or excerpts; there is no accurate account of which shrines were included, or how many.
However, these are only remaining from a few districts, and even most of them are copies or excerpts; there is no accurate account of which shrines were included, or total numbers.
However, these are only remaining from a few districts, and even most of them are copies or excerpts; there is no accurate account of which shrines were included, or total numbers.

sen.j: 二十二社
二十二社（明神二十二社）は国家の一大事に朝廷が奉幣した有力神社の22社。
sen.e: The Nijunisha (Myojin Nijunisha) are 22 influential shrines that the imperial court patronized as the most important in the nation.
The Nijunisha (Myojin Nijunisha) are 22 influential shrines that the Imperial Court presented offerings when their country was in a serious state.
sen.cmt: imperial court→Imperial Court ”国家の一大事に朝廷が奉幣した” のくだりを修正（文章の後半）。
sen.e: The Nijunisha (Myojin Nijunisha) are 22 influential shrines that the Imperial Court presented offerings when their country was in a serious state.

sen.j: 国史見在社
国史見在社（こくしけんざいしゃ）は、六国史に記載のある神社のことである。
sen.e: The Kokushi Kenzaisha are the shrines that are listed in the Rokkokushi.
sen.cmt: The title "Rokkokushi" is sometimes translated as "Six National Histories"
sen.e: The Kokushi Kenzaisha are the shrines that are listed in the Rokkokushi.
The Kokushi Kenzaisha are the shrines that are listed in the Rokkokushi.

sen.j: 国史現在社・国史所載社とも言う。
sen.e: Also known as Kokushi Genzaisha or Kokushi Shosaisha.
Also known as Kokushi Genzaisha or Kokushi Shosaisha.
Also known as Kokushi-genzaisha Shrine or Kokushi-shosaisha Shrine.

sen.j: ただし、式内社はほとんどが国史見在社であるため、通常、国史見在社という言葉は式外社について用いる。
sen.e: Actually, because most Shikinaisha are Kokushi Kenzaisha, the term is used for Shikigesha.
However, because most Shikinaisha are Kokushi Kenzaisha, the term of Kokushi Kenzaisha is used for Shikigesha.
sen.cmt: Actually→However 但し、と原文にあるので。
sen.e: However, because most Shikinaisha are Kokushi Kenzaisha, the term of Kokushi Kenzaisha is used for Shikigesha.

sen.j: 近代社格制度とは、明治維新の後、延喜式による社格にならって新たに作られた社格制度である。
sen.e: The Modern Shakaku System is the system that was made anew after the Meiji Restoration, and borrows from the Engi-shiki Shakaku.
The Modern Times Shakaku System is the system that was made anew based on the Engi-shiki after the Meiji Restoration.
The Modern Times Shakaku System is the system that was made anew based on the Engi-shiki after the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後、連合国軍最高司令官総司令部による神道指令によって廃止された。
sen.e: It was abolished after the 2nd World War by General Headquarters' Shinto Shirei program.
It was abolished after the 2nd World War by General Headquarters' Shinto Shirei program.
It was abolished after the 2nd World War by General Headquarters' Shinto Shirei program.

sen.j: 詳細は近代社格制度を参照のこと。
sen.e: Refer to The Modern Shakaku System for details.
Refer to The Modern Times Shakaku System for details.
sen.cmt: 近代社格制度の表現を、上記と統一する為に修正。
sen.e: Refer to The Modern Times Shakaku System for details.

sen.j: 近代社格制度の社格の順は以下の通り。
sen.e: The ranking order of the Modern Shakaku System was as follows.
The ranking order of the Modern Times Shakaku System was as follows.
sen.cmt: 近代社格制度の表現を、上記と統一する為に修正。
sen.e: The ranking order of the Modern Times Shakaku System was as follows.

sen.j: 官国幣社（官社）
官幣大社
国幣大社
官幣中社
国幣中社
官幣小社
国幣小社
別格官幣社
諸社（民社）
府社・県社・藩社
郷社
村社
無格社
上記の近代社格制度とは別に、以下の制度が定められた。
sen.e: In addition to the present day Shakaku system above, the following system was established.
In addition to the Modern Times Shakaku System above, the following system was established.
sen.cmt: 近代社格制度の表現を、上記と統一する為に修正。
sen.e: In addition to the Modern Times Shakaku System above, the following system was established.

sen.j: 勅祭社
sen.cmt: 勅祭（及び勅祭社）→A festival celebrated on the occasion of a visit by a specially dispatched imperial messenger (chokushi). This festival is performed at more than ten shrines, called chokusaisha,

sen.j: 東京十社（準勅祭社）
sen.cmt: 十社にはshrineの意味が含まれているので、重ならないように修正。

sen.j: 内務大臣指定護国神社－（護国神社のうち、政府の保護を受けたもの）
sen.e: Home Minister Designated Gokoku Shrines (Gokoku shrines under the protection of the government)
Gokoku Jinja (shrine) designated by the Home Minister (Gokoku Jinja under the protection of the government)
sen.cmt: 護国神社を上記に倣い（これだけshrinesとなっている）、日本語読みを補足。
sen.e: Gokoku Jinja (shrine) designated by the Home Minister (Gokoku Jinja under the protection of the government)

sen.j: 神社本庁では、神社本庁が包括している有力神社の一部を別表神社として定めている。
sen.e: The Jinja-Honcho designates some of the influential shrines that it overseas as Beppyo-Jinja.
The Jinja-Honcho designates some of the influential shrines that it oversees as Beppyo-Jinja.
The Jinja-Honcho designates some of the influential shrines that it oversees as Beppyo-Jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 神階
寺格
神宮
神社一覧
神道
